comments_text: Things to keep in mind: - all patients must be billed equally, you only have 1 charge sheet. This does not change depending on how someone can pay (insurance vs non-insurance) - in general, all charges and possible discounts must be available to all patients equally, providing they meet the guidelines (my assumption here is that "former patient" status would be considered an arbitrary guideline based on legal aspects, but IANAL) - discounts after the fact can be applied depending on circumstances, as long as legal guidelines are followed (such as a documented financial hardship form) - if someone pre-paid for services before the price change went into effect, those would be grandfathered in (to the best of my knowledge, again, IANAL, just very interested in safeguarding my own practice). There are patient safeguards and license requirements that disallow the charge for a service to be different for patients based on arbitrary guidelines (like old vs new patients). Grandfathering may be nice, but you'd want to consult actual legal advice based on your local laws in conjunction with national laws to make sure you're not putting yourself in a legally compromised position. In reality, when I raised my cash pay rates $25 for an hour of service I gave my current patients 2 months notice and let them know that in trying to balance a reasonable cost vs service vs keeping the doors open, that's where the numbers ended up. I had zero cancellations from those conversations because I let them know in advance and discussed the legal restrictions I have in regards to having a single charge master.

It‚Äôs that cash practices expect being cash + good clinical care to magically solve hiring and filling schedules. That works when you‚Äôre solo. It breaks the second you hire. When you were alone, you had low overhead and lots of time. You could network, run workshops, meet people, hustle. Your hire is not going to do that at the same level, and they shouldn‚Äôt be expected to. At that point, you need real systems. Cash pay clinics that scale well all have a few things in place: ‚Ä¢ Strong sales skills from the first phone call through the eval ‚Ä¢ Clear package presentation (you have to sell packages) ‚Ä¢ Continuity options so people don‚Äôt disappear once pain improves ‚Ä¢ An intentional marketing channel that doesn‚Äôt rely on the owner‚Äôs time On the insurance side, one thing I saw in the comments stood out. If BCBS reimburses better than your cash rates, that‚Äôs a pricing issue. Your cash rates are too low. I totally get wanting to help more people, but once you charge anything above $0, you‚Äôre already excluding someone. So you might as well price in a way that lets you run a sustainable business, pay staff well, and not burn out. Don‚Äôt pick prices everyone can afford. Pick prices that support the business and the life you want. Multi-specialty can reimburse more, but it also adds complexity and doesn‚Äôt fix weak sales or marketing. Plenty of multi-specialty clinics still struggle for the same reasons. Before jumping in-network, I‚Äôd fix sales, marketing, packaging, and pricing first. Cash pay can work very well, but only when it‚Äôs run intentionally.

Next as an OON provider- credentialing you or your business isn't needed? Also checks of benefits? Do any of you guys do that or leave it up to your patients? comments_text: the superbill can not be more than you charged the patient. if they had reached their out of pocket max, the insurance company would refund all of it. (as long as charges are reasonable and customary) charging more on your superbill than what u charged thebpatient, esp. in this scenario, would constitute insurance fraud. second point, documentarion is a state board requirement. whether u are in or OON.(assuming care is skilled)..board requirementsdo not change for skilled care

I have my rates for all CPTs codes. So for an eval I charge $250 and the patient pays that at the time of service. I provide a superbill with the code, rate, what the patient paid. Then patient submits that to their insurance. If they have an OON Deductible it will get applied to that. Once that is met the insurance will reimburse them based on their fee schedule. Let‚Äôs say the insurance fee schedule for 97163 is $150. Each visit only $150 is applied to the deductible (even though the patient is paying me $250). Once met the patient has a 30% coinsurance. Insurance will reimburse the patient 70% of $150, so the total cost for the patient is 30% of $150 PLUS the $100 difference between the fee schedules. As the ONN provider is doesn‚Äôt matter because they already paid you $250. They should expect to only be reimbursed $105 (70% of $150) once deductible is met. I have the patient contact their insurance to ask about their ONN benefits. I tried to do it and they would always give me the wrong info so I stopped. If you tell patients you will give them a superbill for possible reimbursement you should make sure your documentation is detailed enough for insurances. Because they may require the patient to submit documentation. Also some plans require you to get prior auth even as OON. You don‚Äôt have to but then the patient won‚Äôt be reimbursed. Again I have the patient find all of that out first. I will also give the patient a W9 form to submit with the superbill if I‚Äôve never had a patient with their insurance in the past.

comments_text: I love that you‚Äôre thinking through this before you jump in, because the way you structure it now is what‚Äôs going to make this collaboration actually work long term. There are a few clean ways to look at it. First option: treat it like you‚Äôre getting free leads. If she wants to keep her pricing exactly the same and not rearrange anything, that can still work. The big thing is you cannot let people just show up at your door expecting free ongoing PT. You need a 15 minute phone call with them first so you can set expectations clearly‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what the eval normally costs, here‚Äôs what this first session looks like inside your DPC membership, and here‚Äôs what people with your issue typically need in terms of sessions.‚Äù Basically give it the full discovery call feel so they understand where the free part ends and where your actual plan of care begins. It becomes a value add for her members and she stays whole financially. My guess is she‚Äôs probably not looking to raise prices, but it‚Äôs still worth mentioning because it‚Äôs the most straightforward version of the model. Third option: she pays you directly per person she sends over. If you go this route, compare it to what you‚Äôd normally spend on acquiring a patient. If you‚Äôre running paid ads, depending on your city you might be paying anywhere from $80 to $150 just to get someone on a phone call. These aren‚Äôt cold traffic leads though. These are warm, already-sold referrals coming from someone they trust. That‚Äôs worth a lot. Your conversion rate on those will typically be double what you get from ads. If you frame it that way, you can structure a win-win so every patient who needs PT goes straight to you as the default, not ‚Äúone of several options.‚Äù She sells it as part of the experience. Just make sure whatever you choose sets expectations properly and positions you as the consistent PT solution for her people. That‚Äôs where this kind of relationship becomes genuinely fruitful instead of chaotic.

You have to be careful with these laws -the easiest way is to just accept referrals from the doc : Federal Anti-Kickback Statute (AKS): Prohibits knowingly offering, paying, soliciting, or receiving any remuneration (cash, gifts, discounts) to induce referrals for services paid by federal programs (Medicare/Medicaid). Violations are felonies with severe penalties (prison, fines, exclusion from programs). Stark Law (Physician Self-Referral Law): Prohibits physicians from referring patients for certain services (like lab work, PT, imaging) to entities they or their family have a financial relationship with (ownership or compensation), unless an exception applies. State Laws: Many states (e.g., Texas) have independent anti-solicitation or anti-kickback laws that can be stricter. Professional Ethics: The APA and other organizations specify that payments should be for services rendered, not based on the referral.

comments_text: #Compliance #ABN "transitioning" - what does this mean? Is the beneficiary completing their medically necessary POC? If so discharge patient and setup a "wellness" or "exercise" program. A mandatory ABN is not necessary, an optional ABN is recommended (read instructions relative to therapy). Are you "stepping down" the frequency, w/beneficiary requesting to maintain frequency? If so, issue Mandatory ABN (coded to claim) to transfer liability to beneficiary. My strong suggestion - review ABN instructions (both ABN general instructions and ABN therapy specific guidance). As for billing for Mandatory ABN - guidance in the instructions - Medicare does not dictate price, only HOW price is stated. Setting rates best practice....?? If you are seeing a Medicare beneficiary and doing something that is skilled you cannot charge cash for that service. If it‚Äôs a non skilled service you can and charge whatever you want. If you have no relationship with Medicare - ie they don‚Äôt know you exist, then there is no way for you to bill Medicare in which case charge whatever you want.
